Inclusive living, agile ageing, technology, and meaningful activity are vital components of a society that values the well-being and fulfillment of all its members. Inclusive living fosters environments where individuals of diverse backgrounds, abilities, and ages can thrive together, promoting social cohesion and reducing disparities. Agile ageing emphasizes the importance of adapting to the evolving needs and capacities of older adults, enabling them to maintain independence, autonomy, and quality of life as they age. Technology plays a transformative role by providing tools and solutions that enhance accessibility, communication, and health management, empowering individuals to lead more fulfilling and connected lives regardless of age or ability. Meaningful activity, whether it's through work, volunteering, or creative pursuits, enriches lives by fostering a sense of purpose, accomplishment, and community engagement. Together, these elements contribute to a society that values inclusivity, embraces diversity, and supports the well-being of all its members across the lifespan. Sensing in those darkest moments there may still be rays of light, or feeling those faintest hints of possibility, of the more beautiful regenerative world? Maybe you wish to evolve your participative capabilities to care for, share and grow those slivers of possibility? Then you might wish to consider my latest course Co-Creating Regenerative Cultures. This short video offers an overview of my core design intentions for the course. Plus I also explain a little about the multi-sectoral learning cohort that is already forming. I participated in a two-day Masterclass on Inner Developmental Goals (IDGs) with Renee Lertzman, PhD. This class resonated with me particularly because in my work with youth on Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), I pay attention to creating spaces to reflect on the question: Who am I becoming by doing what I'm doing? Is this being aligned with the world I would like to co-create? Because of the fast pace of academic/life calendars and operating in product-oriented cultures, it is easy to fall into the trap of focusing on getting the results we want on SDG (youth) projects. While these results do matter, our most significant impact on the world is the beings we become. We will take that footprint wherever we go, whoever we interact with, and whatever project we work on. A project might fail or achieve (un)intended results, but we might miss the point if we do not see it as a tool to evolve into higher versions of ourselves to serve ourselves, each other, and nature. The potential I see with Inner Development Goals is that it might give a common language to unpack what we mean by 'higher versions' of ourselves. This requires deep inner exploration. In this masterclass, I had the opportunity to practice that by reflecting on the questions: 1. What kind of a change maker am I? 2. What is my theory of change? 3. How do I relate to the beings I co-create with? 3. How can I become a guide for sustainability/regeneration? constantly inviting myself to observe how I am showing up. Learning with creatives from different sectors and cultures also allowed me to notice and unpack my blindspots in my understanding of the nature of change. I'm leaving two resources and information on the next IDG Summit here that you might find interesting to explore. I'll be participating in the summit online. Hope to connect there. https://lnkd.in/duaXaPS3 and https://lnkd.in/d49AjNjG
